‘No!’ 

‘When I saw you pretending, I thought, “Here’s the man.”’ 

‘What do you mean?’ Raskolnikov cried. 

Svidrigaïlov shrugged. 

‘That’s nonsense!’ Raskolnikov shouted. 

‘What does she say to you?’ 

‘She talks of silly trifles. It makes me angry. 

The first time she came, she said, “You forgot to wind the clock.” 

I always wound that clock. 

The next day, I saw her at the station. 

‘Shall I tell your fortune?’ she asked with a pack of cards. 

I ran away in fright. I should have asked her.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Svidrigaïlov describes his encounters with the ghost of his deceased wife, Marfa Petrovna, who engages him in trivial conversations.
